text: I hate surfing but man, all my surf bum friends in SoCal would eat this up. Pretty cool take
i object entirely based on the name
that's a terrible name
Not if you're a surfer.
I hope thats true
Well, I think it means no waves... like flat and glassy... but that seems counter-intuitive to what this thing is for... so maybe you're right.
I assumed it was something like that
I just know I can easily picture my surfer friends using that word and sounding cool when they say it. Maybe it works, maybe it doesn't.

attachments.title: This is the Fitbit Surge, a $250 'superwatch' with built-in GPS
attachments.text: Fitbit is preparing to launch three new fitness trackers in the coming weeks. Two of those will be the Charge and Charge HR. The Charge looks to be a revision of the Fitbit Force, which was pulled...
attachments.fallback: The Verge: This is the Fitbit Surge, a $250 'superwatch' with built-in GPS

text: Look out, Mio

Yeah - I'll be taking a look at this one for sure. I'm actually looking at getting a new running watch this winter, so I've been looking at a lot of devices. Right now the TomTom Runner Cardio is my first choice, but this one might take that slot. I like that this one is bridging that gap between serious running watch, everyday tracker, and smart-ish watch
I really have no desire to buy any of the current gen smart watches, but if I had a running a watch that could a bit of that, that might push me towards that
still - 250 is serious money. That's in a pretty competitive space.
<@U0260V4K1> Are you thinking about writing a follow-up to the Wearables Report?

I've thought about it. I'm not sure much has changed from a societal point of view - so there's that. At the same time, we could go slight up market and look at some of the more full featured devices.
I guess since the :apple: watch hasn't hit the market we still need to see how it will influence "normal people's" idea of wearables.
